none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, August 29, 1881
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, August 29, 1881
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 9 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: J. S. Hanna writes to Professor Louis L. McInnis from Brenham, Texas, describing his recent visit to Galveston and reflecting on the city's potential for commercial and economic growth comparable to Baltimore. The letter discusses local civic matters including an upcoming school tax vote and mentions educational figures involved in the University of Texas, particularly praising Hogg's work on behalf of the institution. Hanna also expresses his poor health during his travels and his admiration for Hogg's contributions to the university's development.

body.value:
[Header]
Brenham Texas.
Aug 29 - 88.

My Dear Professor:
I have been
so thoroughly "out of kelter" since
I saw you that I have hesitated
to write anyone. I went
to Galveston on Tuesday after
you left Brenham. Spent two
days in the city - but was too
much unstrung to enjoy either
business or pleasure.
Had a splendid drive & mag-
nificent breeze on the beach.
Galveston is beginning to get
into a business stir.

I looked at the water & RR
facilities of Galveston, with
the vast area of country
tributary to him & asked
myself, Why is not Galveston
such a city as Baltimore?
In the near future Texas
can build up & support such

**Final Transcription and Analysis** Alright, let's get this done. I've got a handwritten letter from 1888 to transcribe. The image is a bit faded, and the handwriting is cursive – a bit hurried, but readable. My task is to produce a transcription, preserving the layout and line breaks as accurately as possible, and following the rules for HTML-like markup. First, I've got the header to handle: "Brenham Texas" and "Aug 29 - 88". Since I can't directly use style attributes, I'll put them on separate lines to roughly mirror the layout. I'm noting the lack of direct layout control as it's not in the guidelines for allowed tags. And those guidelines – a, b, br, i, img, p, small, span, sub, sup – are my only tools here. It says to preserve structural elements, so the date/location will go at the top as they are in the image. The letter starts with "My Dear Professor:". That's a salutation and feels like a separate section. The body of the letter is clearly divided into paragraphs. I'll preserve that structure with `

` tags. And any line breaks within the paragraphs will be handled with `
`. The first line of the body is "I have been", and the real challenge starts with "so thoroughly 'out of kelter' since". It looks like "kelter" and I believe that is the correct word. The word looks like "k-e-l-t-e-r". It is dialectal and fits the context. I'll make sure the quotes are there. The next lines seem straightforward: "I saw you that I have hesitated / to write anyone. I went / to Galveston on Tuesday after / you left Brenham". "Tuesday" looks like "T-u-e-s-d-a-y". "Brenham" is clear: "B-r-e-n-h-a-m". I am preserving the line breaks with `
`. It will be easy enough to wrap the lines in `

` tags. Then comes: "Spent two / days in the city - but was too / much unstrung to enjoy either / business or pleasure. / Had a splendid drive & mag- / nificent breeze on the beach. / Galveston is beginning to get / into a business stir." "Unstrung" is correct: "u-n-s-t-r-u-n-g". "Splendid" is correct: "s-p-l-e-n-d-i-d". "Mag-" is easy enough, and "nificent" is a bit clearer. The rest of the line is a nice "breeze". The next paragraph begins: "I looked at the water & RR / facilities of Galveston, with / the vast area of country / tributary to him & asked / myself, Why is not Galveston / such a city as Baltimore? / In the near future Texas / can build up & support such". There is a distinct line break, and that goes into another paragraph. Let's start a new `

`. Ah, the trickier bits. The "water & RR" is underlined in the original, but, since I can't use ``, I will transcribe that text as it is. It will just be written. I will note this in the transcription details. The final word on that line: It's "him". It's odd; in context, "her" or "here" might make more sense for a city but "him" is what is written. Let's assume it refers to a particular person, perhaps a male Galvestonian, or a peculiar choice. I'm not going to guess or change what's there. The next line, "Why is not Galveston" - the "Why" is capitalized. I will respect that. The last line is faded but looks like it ends with the word "such". There is no more. "Texas" is clear. I will end the transcription there. No more information. I'm ready to render: ```html

[Header]
Brenham Texas.
Aug 29 - 88.

My Dear Professor:
I have been
so thoroughly "out of kelter" since
I saw you that I have hesitated
to write anyone. I went
to Galveston on Tuesday after
you left Brenham. Spent two
days in the city - but was too
much unstrung to enjoy either
business or pleasure.
Had a splendid drive & mag-

[Header]

[1881, Aug. 29]

Coach two such cities as
Baltimore. I found Capt
Bowen in the city & he was
most kind to me. as also
Capt Rogers. Had I been
well I should have had
a delightful time
I saw His Honor the Mayor Col
Findlay, Col. Fulton, who are
officially connected with
the school interests of the
city - The city will vote on
the tax question 6th Sept -
Some are sanguine that
the tax will carry _ others are
in doubt. I don't say how
I impressed the gentlemen
named above - I was
certainly in bad condition
to act the agreeable - Well I
have known men to overdo
the thing, which is little better
than to undo a thing.
"There is a divinity that shapes our ends"

**Transcribing a Historical Letter: A Detailed Examination**

Okay, so I've got this fascinating handwritten document, and my task is to get a perfect transcription. First, I need to understand what I’m looking at. It's a single page of cursive handwriting, a bit faded and slanted, and there's a date right at the top, a penciled annotation: [1881, Aug. 29]. That immediately suggests this is something archival, like a letter. The handwriting looks like it would have been from someone educated, in the 19th Century. The writing isn't quite clear, but I can make out mentions of places like Baltimore, and some names like "Capt Bowen," "Capt Rogers," "His Honor the Mayor," and figures like "Col Findlay," and possibly "Col Fulton," that is what I think it looks like. There’s something about school interests, a tax vote, and some personal impressions.

So, I'm going to carefully read this line by line and try to interpret. 

Line one is a bit of a head scratcher. It starts with a capital 'C' then has a word that is hard to decipher. It looks like "Coach", but "Coach two such cities as". It doesn't make total sense but makes the most visual sense. I need to make some decisions, and "Coach" is the best transcription and I'll see if the rest of the text clarifies what is said. 

So it sounds like "Coach two such cities as Baltimore." Then I read the next lines that say "...I found Capt Bowen in the city & he was / most kind to me. as also / Capt Rogers." So, the writer is visiting. This probably means "Coach to such cities as...".

So, I start transcribing, being as accurate as I can line by line. I have to read words multiple times, trying different interpretations. I'm really looking for clues in the letter. I'm considering "Boast", "Count" and "Coast" as well. I'm taking in the full visual context.

The second line starts with "Baltimore" so I can assume it is "Coach two such cities as Baltimore." The "Capt" looks like the shortened "Captain". Then I go line by line, writing the letters as written.

Then I am reading about "Col. Findlay" and the "Mayor Col".

After reading about the voting on tax, I start to re-read the first line again. I am still uncertain.

I am looking at "coach", "coast", "count" and "catch". "Count two such cities as". Visually, it is hard to say with certainty. It looks like "Coach" visually but I keep thinking that I can interpret "Coach" as "Count". However, I'll transcribe "Coach two such cities as" but I suspect it might be "Count".

Then I keep going. "Col. Fulton" is another tough name. I'm looking at "Col. Fenton", but it looks more like "Col. Fulton" because of the way the "l" is written. 

In general, the letter mentions "Capt Bowen", "Col Findlay" and "Col Fulton", so I should read it as a whole and trust the full context of the document.

Then I read all the other letters carefully again, looking for any words that may have a different interpretation.

The transcription is ready.

[Header]
[1881, Aug. 29]

Ye shades of Aristotle Pythagoras!
The ninteenth Century is full
surprises - What next?
Suppose you have seen
Hoggs "Paper on the University of
Texas". I am sure the Board
of Regents will give him a
vote of thanks - if they do not
make him Chancellor.
He has completed their
work for them. From pit to
dome - Incorrigible, impossible
my vocabulary fails - He is a
wonder - a startle & will
yet "turn up" -
No doubt you have had
a pleasant time - wish I
could take just such
a trip - but impecuniosity -
What a cruel tyrant!
Mrs H is at Galveston - Rest of the
family in reasonable health -
I am rather "under the weather" -
Let me hear from you. Your friend
[Signature]
J. S. Hanna

**Final Thoughts Before Transcription** Alright, let's get this done. I've broken down the request, analyzed the image – it's a handwritten letter from 1881, faded cursive on lined paper. My job is to be faithful to the original, spelling and all, and only use approved HTML tags. First, I'll transcribe line by line. Top right is the date: `[1881, Aug. 29]`. Then comes the body, with each line being carefully reviewed. I'm noting any uncertainty with `[?]` and marking illegible sections as `[illegible]`. I'll preserve the layout as best as I can, line breaks and all. I'll flag spelling peculiarities – like "ninteenth" – and maintain the intended meaning. I am looking carefully at "Galveston". It looks like Galveston. The handwriting is a bit rough in places – "reasonable" for instance. Also, "impecuniosity" is clear, and the signature will be transcribed to the best of my ability, as "J. S. Hanna". Now I format with the HTML, using `

` for blocks, `
` for line breaks. I'll double-check for any missed details or formatting errors and then cross-check the HTML tags used. Then I will submit the transcription. Here we go.
